p.s: China is home to many diverse and ancient cultures , thus
Chinese people traditionally have certain superstitions .
When in China or interacting with Chinese culture , it is best to learn and understand these superstitions to avoid offending people .

item.s: Avoid the number 4 whenever possible . 四(four ) is pronounced si ( 四 sì ( si ) [ ssuh ] - like a snake with ' uh ' ( say the vowel in the back of your throat ) ) .
The word for " death " 死 is pronounced si ( with falling intonation ) .
Because of the similarities in pronunciation , the Chinese avoid anything to do with 4 .

figure.rend: Understand and Respect Chinese Superstitions Step 1.jpg

item.s: Some buildings may " lack " a fourth floor .
Avoid giving gifts in sets of four .
Some more modern buildings may also lack a thirteenth floor , having adopted the Western superstitions .
Celebrate eight .
In contrast , the number 8 is considered extremely auspicious .
It is associated with wealth .

figure.rend: Understand and Respect Chinese Superstitions Step 2.jpg

item.s: Avoid giving anyone ( particularly the elderly ) clocks .
The Chinese word for clock 钟 ( zhong1 ) is pronounced exactly the same as the word for end 终 .
Giving a clock as a gift in Chinese culture is the equivalent of wishing death upon someone .

figure.rend: Understand and Respect Chinese Superstitions Step 3.jpg

item.s: Avoid offering pears to close friends .
The Chinese word for pear 梨 ( li2 ) is pronounced the same as 离 , meaning to leave .
Giving pears to friends is considered bad luck , as it is considered an omen for the end of your friendship .

figure.rend: Understand and Respect Chinese Superstitions Step 4.jpg

item.s: Avoid giving shoes to friends or significant others .
Giving shoes implies that you want them to walk out of your life .

figure.rend: Understand and Respect Chinese Superstitions Step 5.jpg

item.s: When in doubt , wear or use red .
Red is an auspicious color in Chinese culture .

figure.rend: Understand and Respect Chinese Superstitions Step 6.jpg

item.s: Avoid giving white gifts , or gifts wrapped in white .
Unlike in the West , where black signifies death , China uses white for the same purpose .

figure.rend: Understand and Respect Chinese Superstitions Step 7.jpg

item.s: Celebrate with noise .
Fireworks were used in ancient times to frighten bad spirits .
Fireworks in China , particularly 鞭炮 , are loud .
These are used during holidays like 春节 ( Chinese New Year ) to frighten away spirits who would bring bad luck .

figure.rend: Understand and Respect Chinese Superstitions Step 8.jpg

item.s: Clean out the old .
Cleaning during the New Year will bring good luck .
You essentially " sweep out " the old .

figure.rend: Understand and Respect Chinese Superstitions Step 9.jpg

item.s: Eat fish on 除夕 but leave some leftovers .
Chinese has a saying " 年年有鱼 , 年年有余 " , meaning that if you have fish every year , then every year you 'll have surplus ; however , you need to leave surplus in order for this work .

figure.rend: Understand and Respect Chinese Superstitions Step 10.jpg

item.s: Hang 福 upside down on your door or in your house .
The word 福 ( fu2 ) means happiness or prosperity .
By hanging it upside down ( 倒 dao ) then 福 will arrive ( 到 dao ) .

figure.rend: Understand and Respect Chinese Superstitions Step 11.jpg

item.s: Learn the interactions between superstitions and pregnancy/birth :

figure.rend: Understand and Respect Chinese Superstitions Step 12.jpg

item.s: During pregnancy , women must be very careful about what animals they interact with .
The presence of some animals is said to influence the characteristics of their baby .
Women avoid cutting their hair during pregnancy and after birth .
Some women believe it will affect the life expectancy of the child .
Many Chinese families will plan their child 's birth to coincide with certain years .
Every year is represented by a different Chinese zodiac animal .
Most often , people will aim for the year of the Dragon or Pig and avoid the year of the Sheep .
Eat noodles to celebrate .
On birthdays , Chinese people eat a special kind of noodle .
These noodles are very long , symbolizing longevity .

figure.rend: Understand and Respect Chinese Superstitions Step 13.jpg

item.s: Understand feng shui .
Feng shui 风水 is the Chinese art of balance .
Homes , businesses ( and originally graves ) are designed in certain ways to maximize benefit and maintain an overall balance of qi .

figure.rend: Understand and Respect Chinese Superstitions Step 14.jpg

item.s: Avoid facing beds near doors .
Certain locations are associated with certain elements .
Avoid clutter , which disrupts the flow of qi .
